name: NewYorker
text: In Los Mochis, in the El Fuerte region of Mexico, a group of about 100 people scour the countryside, searching for the bodies of desaparecidos—the disappeared—victims of cartel-related violence. https://t.co/9iuoNlpfWb

name: NewYorker
text: The disappearances began nearly 15 years ago, shortly after Felipe Calderón became the President of Mexico and launched the country’s war on drug trafficking. https://t.co/YFqdL8aFGh https://t.co/NQLHP12hte

name: NewYorker
text: "He woke to discover that he had undergone a metamorphosis and become Gregor Samsa." Fiction by Haruki Murakami, from 2013. https://t.co/WaBGLFSJH1

name: NewYorker
text: They buried the bodies in shallow pits. At the time Calderón was elected, two such pits had been identified. Five years later, the number grew to 350. By the beginning of this year, secret graves were being found, on average, nearly every other day. https://t.co/YFqdL8aFGh https://t.co/OQ7kVXWtpv

name: NewYorker
text: For myriad reasons, Black Americans will have a harder time rebounding economically from the pandemic. But bold government action could help. https://t.co/4QhQFKMR7P

name: NewYorker
text: As tuberculosis shaped modernism, so COVID-19 and our collective experience of staying inside for months on end will influence architecture’s near future, @chaykak writes. https://t.co/8WdTF5x54n
